title: Dear White Supremacy
lyrics:
Dear White Supremacy,

First of all you are not really that supreme. 
While throughout history White Supremacy it must be admitted you have achieved some very dominant positions.
 
These positions have been gained mostly through force or some biological agent such as disease that did a lot of the dirty work for you in advance. I mean and anybody can use force on an unarmed populous and anybody can have smallpox
. 
Not judging, just wanted to point out that having a disease that native folks aren't immune to because they've never seen it doesn't make you strategically smart or tactically superior, just kind of sick.
 
And these dominant positions don't really stand up to the test of time that long either.
 There is nothing about you biologically or physically that denotes an innate mode of supremacy. For that matter there is also nothing about you psychologically, philosophically, cognitively, academically, socially, architecturally, culturally or even financially that signifies a higher position above any other group. 
And to be diplomatic there is nothing about you that denotes innate inferiority as well. So what you really are is something in the middle. You are regular. White Regularity is congruent to all other forms of regularity i.e. Black, Brown, Etc etc. But in regularity there is room for differences and this is where White Regularity shines! Each group gets the same essential universals. Dance, food, music, etc. and it must be admitted that the White Regularity take on these universal institutions has been unbelievably impressive and a great addition to the total world culture
. 
I mean spaghetti and meatballs, Romeo & Juliet, Coldplay, The Tuxedo, lighter than air travel are all world class additions to the collective bucket
 but they are no less or more impressive than every other regular groups take on the universals either. 
And if we really wanted to get analytical every invention is built on inspiration from a previously existing invention
 so the claim of "The Supreme 1st" to do something is highly debatable and except for a few exceptions, impossible! All things human aren't born from a supreme overlord solely working in isolation.
Things are created in collaboration and in tandem with other cultures, knowledge structures and movements and more important, People. I mean if those Muslims didn't catalog all that Greek philosophy for research we might not even know who Plato was
. Now whether this collaboration is forced which is seen so much but not exclusively throughout human history does not take away the fact that it is done with the help of somebody else. 
We are supreme as a spectrum of colors in collaboration. One color does not dominate the other nor can it. Sure Steve Jobs was white. But the guy who built the computer was probably Chinese. And the girl who wrote the programs for the computer is probably from Mumbai. And the raw materials that were used to make it where probably first pulled out of the ground by somebody in South Africa.
 And if you take this highly collaborated upon piece of high technology to an indigenous tribe in the jungles of Brazil they'd probably use it as a boat paddle. And we can go on and on down or up the rabbit hole all day long and you'll always find a regular somebody relying on the abilities of a just as regular somebody else that another regular somebody doesn't even care about. White Supremacy is a lie white regularists tell to themselves in hopes that they can get a one way ticket to the top and hope we other colors overhear it. 
Here's the bad news, ain't no top. Here's the good news though, ain't no bottom neither!
 
It's just the regular ole middle where nobody is safe from being influenced by somebody else's extreme regularness.
 Is your swastika flag printed in Mexico? 
Did you know the swastika is officially from Asia and the subcontinent?
 
Did you know black people had slaves in Africa too?
 
Did you know in the world your considered a minority too?
 
I mean you call us niggers and beaners but you gotta ship all your former Native American land backwood sourced ginseng to China to get money to support your meth habit
. Meth that's made with chemicals produced in India. I mean Hitler hated everything about the Jews expect every possession they had. It's funny how the things you hate so much you have to rely on the most for your survival.
And if you wanted to get really ironic and meta about it, White Supremacy has to validate it's on identity based solely on its relationship to other races! I mean now that's what I would call joined at the hip. Without us there is no white supremacy because there would be nothing to supreme over! That sounds so stupid but sometimes the truth is stupid.
 
Stupid like a fox. And no not stupid like a Fox News I mean the real fox. The animal.

In closing white regularity (the race formerly know as white supremacy) I myself on behalf of my own black regularity salute you. Good luck with the northwest front I hear it's beautiful in the spring and probably a strategic death trap if and when 
Yellowstone finally decides to blow up!

Yours Truly

Wasalu "Lupe" Jaco
summary:
The above lyrics are a powerful critique of White Supremacy and the idea of racial hierarchy. The speaker challenges the notion of white superiority, pointing out that all races are equal and contribute to the world in different ways. The lyrics highlight the interconnectedness of different cultures and races, emphasizing that collaboration and diversity are essential for progress and innovation.

The speaker also addresses the hypocrisy of White Supremacy, pointing out that many of the things they claim as their own are actually influenced by other cultures. The mention of the swastika, slavery in Africa, and reliance on products from different countries serves to emphasize that no race is truly superior and that everyone is interconnected.

The lyrics also touch on the absurdity of White Supremacy, highlighting the irony that they have to validate their own identity based on their relationship to other races. The speaker ultimately wishes White Supremacy good luck in their endeavors, implying that their beliefs are ultimately self-destructive.

Overall, the lyrics serve as a powerful and thought-provoking critique of racism and the false notion of racial superiority. They urge listeners to reconsider their beliefs and embrace diversity and unity instead.

The verses also touch on themes of community, resilience, and the struggles faced by Black individuals. References to historical figures and events add depth to the message, highlighting the significance of unity and perseverance in the face of adversity.

The metaphors used throughout the song paint a picture of beauty, strength, and resilience in the Black community. References to Georgia, Alabama, and H-Town (Houston) add a sense of place and history to the lyrics, grounding the message in a specific cultural context. Overall, the lyrics convey a message of empowerment, love, and solidarity within the Black community. They celebrate the beauty and strength of Blackness while also acknowledging the challenges and struggles faced by Black individuals. The song encourages listeners to embrace their identity and support one another in the fight against injustice.

title: HOMME MADE
lyrics:
[Spoken Interlude: Virgil Abloh]
Have you ever asked yourself where the world is inside the solar system?
Like, where are we?
Like, where does the planet sit amongst all the stars?
Who knows, it's a super brain freeze
But an easier question than that is to ask yourself
Where we sit in the sea of art history
Like, that's tangible, that's man-made
Man-made art, so the history of it, we fit in
Another like, sort of framework to dwell on is, like, where do we live?
You know, you live in a house
I guarantee the house that you grew up in is what you define as a house
But, for someone that grew up on the opposite side of the world
What they grew up in, they think of as a house
A kitchen, a living room, a roof, a door, etcetera
Just shit to think about, you know
Whole bullet point is, the world inside it is man-made
It's all metaphoric, man has flaws
Man loves power, everything is man-made
And, what's more dangerous than that?
But, as I digress
summary:
The spoken interlude by Virgil Abloh suggests a reflection on humanity's place within different frameworks - the solar system, art history, and the concept of home. He questions where we stand in relation to the vastness of the universe, where we fit in the history of art, and how our perceptions of something as simple as a house can vary based on cultural context.

The overall theme that emerges from Abloh's words is the idea of man-made constructs and systems, and the inherent flaws and dangers that come with them. He highlights the power dynamics, flaws, and influences of mankind on the world we inhabit. The metaphor of the world as man-made emphasizes the impact and consequences of human actions on the environment and society.

Abloh's musings encourage listeners to think critically about the structures and systems that shape our understanding of the world, and to consider our place within them. The interlude serves as a reminder of the complexities of human existence and the importance of introspection and questioning our perspectives.

The lyrics seem to touch on themes of confidence, skill, and competition in the rap game. Both Lupe Fiasco and Chris Brown showcase their lyrical prowess and their ability to freestyle and rhyme effortlessly. They are both showing off their talents and their ability to hold their own in the rap industry.

There are also metaphors used throughout the lyrics, such as Lupe Fiasco referencing having a clock on his chest like Flavor Flav, symbolizing his dedication and commitment to his craft. Chris Brown's mention of rims on his whip and Tims on his feet could symbolize his success and status in the music industry.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of self-assurance, determination, and skill in their craft. It shows the competitive nature of the rap game and the drive to excel and stand out amongst their peers.

title: Revenge Begins (Intro)
lyrics:
[Interlude]
"Fahrenheit 1/15, Part II
Revenge of the Nerds"

"Mom packs us a lunch and we're off to school
They call us nerds 'cause we're so uncool
They laugh at our clothes, they laugh at our hair
The girls walk by with their nose in the air
So go ahead, put us down
One of these days we'll turn it around
Won't be long, mark my words
Time has come for revenge of the nerd—"

"Every day, every day [?] Jesus. No more, come on. Hello? Okay. Last straw, the last straw. Imbeciles. Every day it's the same thing. "Hey you, hey four eyes." Four eyes. "Hey mamas boy." I'll show you. I'll show you who the smart one is. Let's see here. One more turn. Yes, yes. So you've got a nice car? So you've got a pretty girlfriend? Nothing (Systems online) morons. Finally I will have my revenge! Hahahahahahahaha! It works! (Are you ready?)"
"Lupe Fiasco is here."
"I will have my revenge!"
"Lupe Fiasco, Chicago's own! 1st & 15th, F&F. Lupe Fiasco."
"Revenge of the Nerd"
"Fahrenheit"
"1/15"
"1st & 15th"
"Lupe Fiasco"
"1st & 15th in the building"
"Fahrenheit 1/15"
"Chicago"
"[?]"
"Grew up in Chicago, westside"
summary:
The interlude "Fahrenheit 1/15, Part II: Revenge of the Nerds" by Lupe Fiasco explores the theme of overcoming adversity and societal stereotypes. The lyrics depict the experience of being bullied and marginalized for being different, whether it be for academic interests, appearance, or social status. The nerds in the song are portrayed as resilient individuals who are determined to prove their worth and turn the tables on those who have underestimated them.

The imagery of being called names like "four eyes" and "mama's boy" highlights the hurtful words and actions that can be inflicted on those who do not conform to societal norms. However, the nerds in the song refuse to be defined by these labels and instead focus on empowering themselves to seek revenge and assert their intelligence and capabilities.

The idea of "revenge of the nerd" symbolizes a triumph of the underdog, as the nerds in the song plan to rise above their oppressors and showcase their true potential. Through perseverance and determination, they aim to defy expectations and prove that being different does not equate to being inferior.

Overall, the interlude speaks to the importance of self-confidence, resilience, and the ability to challenge stereotypes in order to overcome prejudice and discrimination. It serves as a powerful anthem for anyone who has ever felt marginalized or underestimated, urging them to embrace their uniqueness and strive for success on their own terms.

summary:
The lyrics from Lupe Fiasco's "Enemy of the State" suggest that he views himself as someone who is opposed by the establishment or mainstream music industry, hence the title "Enemy of the State." He sees himself as a rebel or outsider, but he also feels supported and loved by his fans who appreciate his unique perspective and music.

The reference to it being a love story could suggest that despite facing challenges and opposition, Lupe Fiasco feels a strong connection and affection for his fans who continue to support him. The mention of love could also highlight the emotional bond between the artist and his audience, creating a sense of unity and understanding.

Overall, these lyrics convey themes of defiance, resilience, and appreciation for one's supporters. The metaphor of being an "enemy of the state" could represent the artist's refusal to conform to mainstream norms and his willingness to challenge the status quo in pursuit of his artistic vision.

title: Sway in the Morning (2015 Freestyle)
lyrics:
[Verse]
Represent intelligence I did it before

When I came through, sold out all the albums in the store

Now we bout to backtrack
When I first started I was seventeen
Came up in the game, had a ring, had a chain, had some things

L.A. Reid
, did my thing on the page

Yea, I was growin’ stage up
And when I got up on that joint, I was blowing stage up
Now, I’m back in the rage I said the stage twice
That’s cause I set the stage, so nice

You ain’t even catch it so I gotta bring it backwards again
On the stage I was attacking my friends
But I was attacking my foes, save no bitches and save no hoes
Sway, you know how it goes in these streets
How it goes in these beats, how I do it so sweet
How I do it so neat and I wrap it in a package
And I bow-tie that every time that I wrap it
I lost a little breath, this is real time rap
In real time, every time, I real rhyme that
Yes, yes, I will rhyme that
And they can’t do it like I do, they try to but
You know it’s blessings when you come through like this
Impressed like this and how I’m dressed like this
All black cause I’m mourning for my brother
I love Esco, they don’t even know, how much above you
I don’t place anything
I wed the game like a wedding ring
With a diamond set-it-ting
And you know I’m never settling
I rap burn things down like acetylene
I said this before, only wrestling with settling
I only settle if I wrestle with everything
And I mean it from the heart
From the time when I was in the park on the benches I was rapping
Snapping, trapping and doing my thing
Yea I did the street a lil bit, did the heat a lil bit
Did the beats a lot, and now I can’t stop

Uh, every rapper I embarrass with the flows and the structure
The beats, rhymes and rhythms
How I give ‘em, how I put it together in exorcisms
How it skz’s like a schism
Bring scissors how I cut through the rhythm and bring it back again
And again, and again
Shout to all my friends, shout to all my brothers, all my lovers
I love y’all
And shout to Young Thugga, you a good lil dude
I like the way you rap too
See, there’s blessings in this
It’s a message in this, it ain’t no testin’ in this
Now, let’s get back to the narrative I signed to Atlantic
And everything was good
Until 
Craig Kallman
 called WGCI and said “stop playin’ Kick, Push”
We was like “what the fuck?!”
Fuck are you doin? Tried to bring my crew down
Tried to ruin us
But you didn’t know what you was puttin’ into in us
Then Chill got locked up and everything stopped
I wanted to stop rapping, but I couldn’t
On the phone when I’m cryin’ like “I couldn’t”

At least for me, your family, you gotta bury songs
That mean you gotta dead ‘em
Every time you got in the studio he put the Glock to ‘em and head ‘em “bang!”

summary:
These lyrics seem to be reflecting on the journey of the artist, Lupe Fiasco, in the music industry. He talks about his early days starting out at a young age, facing challenges and setbacks, but continuing to persevere and grow as an artist. The lyrics touch on themes of resilience, dedication, and the struggles of navigating the industry.

There are also themes of loyalty and friendship, with shoutouts to fellow artists and collaborators who have supported him along the way. The lyrics mention both the highs and lows of his career, from selling out albums to facing setbacks and challenges with record labels.

Metaphors such as "wedding the game like a wedding ring" and "rap burn things down like acetylene" convey the intensity and commitment he has to his craft. The lyrics also show a sense of pride and love for his craft, as well as a willingness to continue pushing boundaries and evolving as an artist.

So let's end it here! Big shouts to Everyone who participated in the final session of #PhilosophySunday! I hope you enjoyed it!!!

Special shouts to everyone who struck #TwitterGold and the always vigilant and helpful @wirelessphi <----- follow them! #PS

The "Uomo Mangiato Tigre" will be on public display @ Soho House Chicago starting January 23rd along with some of my other paintings #PS

High quality prints of "The Mangiato" will be available shortly from WOLFstudio as well as posters and other little knick-knacks
#PS

Tetsuo & Youth will be available 1/20/15 and if you what to grab a tshirt or hoodie of the album cover visit:
http://www.lupefiascostore.com

Thanx again...and for the final time...#PS is out!
summary:
The above tweets discuss the interpretation of the painting "Uomo Mangiato Tigre" (Man Eating Tiger), exploring various themes such as the struggle between man and society, the duality of human nature, the impact of technology on humanity, and the eternal battle between instinct and rationality.

The painting is seen as a representation of the inner conflicts and external pressures faced by individuals in society, with the tiger symbolizing societal constraints and the man representing the individual trying to navigate and survive in this environment.

The use of colors and elements in the painting, such as the skull, flesh, blood, bone, soul, and technology, add layers of meaning to the artwork, highlighting themes of resilience, technology's influence, the human-animal connection, and the eternal pursuit of life and death.

Overall, the interpretation of the painting "Uomo Mangiato Tigre" is subjective, with each viewer finding their own meaning and connection to the artwork. The discussion on #PhilosophySunday highlighted the complexity and depth of the painting, inviting viewers to reflect on their own interpretations and understandings of the piece.

title: Lupe Fiasco Named Musical Director of World Cup Team
lyrics:
U.S. Soccer has named Grammy Award-winning recording artist Lupe Fiasco as the Music Director for the Men’s National Team and artist Futura the Art Director for the Men’s National Team’s 2014 FIFA World Cup campaign.

Building on the 
“One Nation. One Team.”
 theme, Chicago-born and Grammy-winning hip-hop artist Fiasco will collaborate with U.S. Soccer in a variety of areas during the Send-Off Series and the World Cup. He will be creating Spotify playlists, in collaboration with his DJ group the SNDCLSH, and handle in-game music programming during the Send-Off Series.

U.S. Soccer is working to promote 
Fiasco’s new single, “Mission,”
 during the Send-Off Series. The single, which is about the fight against cancer, was released on Monday. Fiasco will appear in Times Square in New York during Fan Appreciation Day on May 30, and he will hold a music set in Chicago at the U.S. Soccer Fan Fest prior to the USA’s match against Ghana on June 16.


New York native Futura
, world renowned for his pioneering role in the birth of graffiti-style artwork and designs, will provide his own flavor that will include the official Men’s National Team World Cup poster, limited-edition skate deck designs and other limited-edition items. Futura’s signature style will be tied to the team during the U.S. MNT’s road to Brazil, and he will create two “live” works at the Fan Appreciation Day on May 30 and the U.S. Soccer Fan Fest in Chicago on June 16. Those live works will be auctioned off, with the proceeds benefiting Fiasco’s “Mission” campaign.

Lupe Fiasco, born Wasalu Muhammad Jaco, is a 32-year-old Grammy Award-winning hip hop artist who was once named GQ Magazine’s “Man of the Year” and Rolling Stone Magazine’s “Artist to Watch.” 
Since his breakout hit “Kick Push” in 2006, Fiasco has been praised for his philosophical, sharp and dynamic lyricism.
 His catalogue of albums, 
Food & Liquor, The Cool, LASERS, and Food & Liquor II: The Great American Rap Album Part 1,
 have all received wide critical and commercial success, earning the Chicago-born artist 12 Grammy nominations, numerous RIAA certifications and a No. 1 Billboard Top 200 album.


Fiasco’s fifth studio album, Tetsuo & Youth, is set for release later this year.


Futura, originally known as Futura 2000, is an acclaimed painter, graphic designer, graffiti artist and sports aficionado. He has been a global icon of artistic collaboration for more than 30 years. One of his earliest cross-genre projects included painting live, on-stage murals for the British rock band The Clash. He has since expanded his collaborative horizons, working with apparel designers such as agnès b, Burton and Nike. He has also served, most recently, as theCreative Director for both (RED)’s 2014 global “Dance Red Save Lives” campaign and Sprite’s 2014 NBA All-Star Game art initiative with LeBron James.

Born Leonard McGurr in 1955 in New York, Futura birthed his iconoclastic persona in the streets, and subway tunnels of New York City. He was a friend and contemporary of the legendary Keith Haring. Futura’s abstract art and aerosol strokes have become a staple in public art collections in New York, France,Japan, Hong Kong and Italy. Futura’s artwork and designs have also expanded into additional commercial commissions for the likes of Hennessy/LVMH, A Bathing Ape, Uniqlo, Descente and Levis, to name a few.
summary:
The lyrics provided in the text are not explicitly mentioned, but based on the information given about Lupe Fiasco and his music, it is evident that his songs often touch on social issues, personal struggles, and philosophical themes. Fiasco's music is known for its sharp and dynamic lyricism, and he often uses his platform to address important topics such as cancer, social justice, and personal growth.

Some of the major themes in Fiasco's music could include resilience, perseverance, self-discovery, and the power of music to inspire and bring people together. The metaphor of a "mission" in his new single could symbolize a personal or collective goal to overcome obstacles and make a positive impact on the world.

Overall, Fiasco's music seems to be a blend of introspective storytelling and socially conscious commentary, and his collaboration with U.S. Soccer for the World Cup campaign suggests that his music will be used to inspire and energize both the players and the fans. The inclusion of Futura as the Art Director also adds a visual representation of creativity and innovation to the campaign, creating a multi-sensory experience for the audience.

The beat feel like Sanaa Lathan hair...in slow motion, next to the ocean, wordplay gorgeous, 5 mics no sources, I ain't publicly leaned back bopped in a while especially to this style of a portrait, vulnerable but not tortured, a fortress ain't gotta force it, real time classic, a revival of the corpus, the Tribeca Jay cool but he like for the masses, the Brooklyn Jay a ghoul only suitable for the masters, MARCY ME so fucking stupid! The lyrics seem to be a review and reflection on Jay-Z's album "4:44." The writer mentions that the album dropped while they were overseas and that they had limited access to it due to data plans and coverage limitations. They touch on the personal nature of the album, acknowledging that it made them feel the need to apologize to random women. The writer praises Jay-Z's artistry, wordplay, and vulnerability on the album, specifically highlighting tracks like "Smile" and "Marcy Me."

The use of metaphors throughout the lyrics helps to convey the writer's admiration for Jay-Z's work. References to Jay-Z as a baseline bully and likening the beats to Sanaa Lathan's hair in slow motion show a deep appreciation for the music and production on the album. The comparison of the Tribeca Jay to the Brooklyn Jay highlights the duality of Jay-Z's persona and his ability to appeal to both mainstream and more niche audiences.

Overall, the lyrics express a deep respect and admiration for Jay-Z's skill as an artist and the impact of his music on the listener. The writer's review is glowing, giving the album a perfect score of 10/10 and emphasizing its status as a timeless classic.

The references to weapons and violence suggest a readiness to engage in verbal and lyrical battles.

The metaphor of "skirting around the issues" implies evasion and cowardice, while the comparison of the rival to a clown wearing a crown of sickles portrays them as foolish and dangerous. Just like elephants everybodies pockets hella thick
Koopa wonders this but for now well say it's tenative
Reality shows stars always show intelligence
And nobody would have to beef because we all be gettin rich

I know this this type of dream seems like a stretch
But everyone of us would be the best
With plenty of money
Yea everyone of us would see the change
And we would never have to worry bout dealing with stress
Cause really none of us would be depressed
We would do what we wanted
Ya couldn't tell me that that wouldn't be freshhhh

[Hook:]


[Lupe Fiasco:]
Uh, and I know it's just a fantasy I cordially invite you to
Ask why can't it be?
Now we can do nothing bout the past
But we can do something about the future that we have
We can make fast or we can make it last
Every woman Queenin' and every man a Kingin'
When those color lines come we can't see between
We just close our eyes 'til it's all black every-THING


[Hook]
summary:
The lyrics of this song by Lupe Fiasco and Chamillionaire paint a vivid picture of an alternate reality where African Americans and other marginalized groups did not face centuries of oppression and discrimination. The artists imagine a world where black people were not enslaved, where civil rights leaders like Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X lived full lives, and where individuals like Ice Cube and Gucci Mane achieved great success and respect.

The song delves into themes of empowerment, resilience, and unity. It challenges the listener to imagine a world where systemic racism and inequality never existed, and where all individuals are able to achieve their full potential. The lyrics encourage the listener to think about the possibilities for a better future and to take action to create positive change.

The use of imagery such as "all black everything" metaphorically represents a world where black culture, history, and achievements are celebrated and acknowledged without prejudice or erasure. The artists also touch on the importance of education, representation, and economic empowerment in dismantling systems of oppression.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of hope, possibility, and a call to action for a more just and equitable society. By envisioning a world where marginalized communities are uplifted and given equal opportunities, the artists spark important conversations about social justice and the untapped potential of diverse voices and experiences.

summary:
These lyrics from Lupe Fiasco touch on themes of perception, authenticity, and navigating through the complexities of life. 

In the intro, Lupe questions what people say to your face versus behind your back, highlighting the importance of honesty and transparency. He then goes on to describe various aspects of his life, from watching Mos Def in Dubai to dealing with the pressures of fame and success. The lyrics also touch on the idea of staying true to oneself and not letting others dictate your path.

Metaphors such as wearing a sweater in the summer to "weather the odds" and comparing enemies to delivering cards showcase Lupe's lyrical prowess in weaving together complex ideas. Additionally, the mention of vintage, limited edition items and expensive possessions like Cartier watches and Visvim moccasins can be seen as symbols of success and status, but also as a reflection of the fleeting nature of material possessions.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of introspection and resilience, urging listeners to stay true to themselves and navigate through life's challenges with grace and confidence.

title: On The Corner [Remix]
lyrics:

Why would I catch a bullet, dye my clothes and die on it?
I warn ya, Shorty: It's corny on the corner, I'm saying my piece
Only turn my back on The West when I pray to The East
My favorite corner
summary:
These lyrics seem to be talking about the dangers and risks of living in a tough urban environment, especially when it comes to getting involved in illegal activities and conflicts. The references to weightlifting, muscle-building, turnbuckles, and wrestling all convey a sense of physical strength and toughness that is necessary for survival in a dangerous neighborhood. The mention of Sleepy Hollow and Pumpkinhead potentially getting "jacked" adds a sense of impending danger and violence.

The lyrics also touch on themes of loyalty and betrayal, with the protagonist cautioning against trusting others easily and highlighting the importance of staying true to one's roots. The references to The Ultimate Warrior and cage matches suggest a constant struggle to stay alive and defend oneself in a hostile environment. The mention of "reporting to the bing" implies the consequences of getting caught up in criminal activities.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of street smarts and survival instincts, urging the listener to be cautious and aware of the dangers that come with living in a tough neighborhood. The use of metaphors related to wrestling and strength effectively portrays the harsh realities of life in a dangerous urban setting.

summary:
The lyrics seem to be expressing the intense competitiveness and skill required in the world of fighting games, particularly in the context of a tournament setting like Evolution. The hook suggests a sense of impending conflict and a need for preparation and focus. The line about "a lot of killers in this room" could refer to the high level of competition and the intimidating presence of skilled players.

Lupe Fiasco's verse emphasizes his confidence and expertise in the game, using references to specific moves and strategies ("combos," "frame traps," "V-trigger") to show his knowledge and skill. The mention of "Moment 37" alludes to a legendary moment in the fighting game community, highlighting the significance of historical moments and legendary players in the scene.

The line "on the mic, but I fight" could be a metaphor for his ability to excel both as a rapper (on the mic) and as a skilled player in the game (in the fight). The reference to "Mike Ross" could be a nod to another well-known figure in the fighting game community.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of determination, confidence, and readiness for battle, both in the virtual world of the game and in the real-world competition of a tournament. The themes of skill, strategy, and intense competition are central to the message of the song.

title: Tokyo Freeze 4
lyrics:
[Intro]

And you'll get your revenge, and your hands, and your girl"
What's up now?

[Outro]
Uh, uh, Tokyo Freeze all day, uh
summary:
These lyrics tell a story of a DJ who comes from a family of DJs and is caught in a dangerous situation involving drug dealers and jealousy. The DJ's hands are cut off and he is left for dead, but a mysterious voice offers to help him regain his hands and seek revenge in exchange for capturing spirits through his music. 

The major themes in these lyrics include family legacy, betrayal, revenge, music as a form of power, and the supernatural. The DJ's family background in music is both a source of skill and connection to his past, but also puts him in dangerous situations due to his associations with drug dealers. The betrayal and violence he experiences lead him to a supernatural deal, where music becomes a tool for seeking revenge and regaining control of his life.

The metaphors used in the lyrics, such as cutting off the DJ's hands as a symbol of his loss of power and agency, and capturing spirits through music as a way to gain control and achieve revenge, add depth to the story being told. Overall, the lyrics paint a vivid picture of a dark and intense narrative of power struggles and redemption.

The lyrics appear to be reflecting on the artist's journey in the music industry over the past six years. The artist references a "seismic shift" in his career, where he established himself as a talented and thoughtful rapper. Despite facing challenges and ups and downs, the artist remained true to himself and his values. The lyrics also mention the artist's dedication to his craft and his commitment to providing fans with meaningful music.

The themes of growth, perseverance, authenticity, and staying true to one's beliefs are prevalent throughout the lyrics. The artist emphasizes the importance of hard work and honesty in his music, and the lyrics suggest that the upcoming project will showcase both the artist's talent and his ability to challenge and provoke thought.

The use of metaphors such as "wading the water" and "dwell amongst the comets" adds depth to the lyrics, suggesting a journey or struggle that has ultimately led to growth and success. The artist's passion and determination to continue evolving and surprising fans with his music is evident in these lyrics.

summary: These lyrics from Lupe Fiasco's song "We The Best" touch on themes of ego, confidence, success, growth, and self-reflection. The artist acknowledges his own ego and pride, comparing himself to Michael Jackson and his brothers. He talks about facing criticism for his past work, but also embracing his growth and evolution as an artist. The lyrics also touch on the idea of success being measured by both artistic message and commercial success, emphasizing the importance of staying true to oneself and constantly striving for improvement. The metaphor of finding diamonds and luxury items in a fast food meal symbolizes the idea of unexpected success and hidden talent. Overall, the lyrics convey a message of self-assurance, resilience, and perseverance in the face of criticism and doubt.

Overall, these lyrics encourage listeners to persevere, stay strong in the face of adversity, and continue to strive for their goals and dreams, no matter what challenges may come their way.

These lyrics seem to be discussing the lifestyle and mentality of gangsters, as well as the confidence and swagger that comes with it. The hook emphasizes the way gangsters move and groove, suggesting a sense of power and control. Lupe Fiasco's verses further delve into this theme, with references to material possessions like cars, jewelry, and clothes, as well as the smooth-talking persona of a player.

There are also references to overcoming obstacles and showing resilience, as seen in lines like "I promise never to quit, flip, or get softer" and "It's over, once the shoes on surface." The lyrics overall seem to convey a sense of self-assuredness and determination in the face of challenges.

The metaphors used in the lyrics, such as "old folks will point and say" and "Flying when I peel," add a poetic and artistic element to the depiction of the gangster lifestyle. The repetition of the hook and the catchy chorus reinforce the message of moving and grooving like a gangster.

title: Meditations On A New Diasporic Mythology Complex
lyrics:
I think as we begin to think about myth, mythology, and the need of mythology - I was basically raised on mythology, introduced to mythology at a very young age. 
Mostly Greek mythology, and of course of that Roman mythology, which kinda took over what the Greeks left off, and kinda super-imposed themselves on a lotta the Greek myths - very directly  in the form of Hercules, and the -cules.
 And that was the kind of literature I was reading as an adolescent, which became my first kind of education into creation of stories, creation of myths, and it was the role of myth being used to establish certain principles and certain narratives and certain answering of questions why in a very fantastic manner and a very supernatural manner, in that sense. But in some capacities, even a very natural manner.

And so, once you're steeped into kinda that education; that formation; you start to think in those capacities, you start to develop your world views and your outlooks based on those kind of templates, those creation templates. As you think of, you know, that's one aspect, and you start to think of those conscious aspects consciously being attended to, and researching, and being entertained by certain narratives, mythical narrates from a certain period. And then you think of the unconscious narratives, and even you think of modern narratives, which are kind of fast-forwarded through time and the narratives which you are introduced to consciously of a more modern kind of piece: the mythology of America, the mythology of globalization, the mythology of - you know, as it stands. A myth kind of being steeped into a certain misunderstanding, and then trying to achieve the understanding reconcile of your ignorance to a certain degree through this template, this mythical template, which lays everything plain and gives you the A plus B equals C and you go on and live your life, all things are well.

But say you think of the modern mythologies, the mythology of the cowboy, the mythology of the gangsta, the mythology of just these supernatural beings - maybe not as supernatural as Zeus, of course, or Hercules, of course - but still bearing the same, some of the same fascinations with the fantastic. And these great abilities and these grand possessions and levels of influence and power, which are steeps, and the ability to influence specifically, the ability to influence discourse, the ability to influence progressions of ideas, the ability to influence women into the bed, the ability to gather large, vast quantities of material possessions, and not only have them, but to have a disdain for them; to be so above it all, once you have it where these things, where there's a certain aesthetic nature to it, that when you've consumed all of these things and at the same time you have the power to relinquish them, to show that they have no value and the way that you treat to them.

And it's very interesting to classify that as mythology, if you know not of it, if you can't see it first-hand, if you don't really have your own creation-kind-of story as to why things are a certain revealed - it has been revealed to you that this is the way it works, these are the mechanics to this particular situation - you're gonna, in my capacity, you're gonna develop it and through myth, through your interaction with myth, through your self-creation of myth.

And so there's a role of mythology. And I think persuing that role and taking on the role of the author of mythology. Even in the circumstance that what you are, this modern, this real -  let's call it this reality, to, you know, translate it into mythology, to regress it back into mythological kind of structure, it opens up new terrain, it opens up new frontiers for expedition: for literary expedition, for critical expedition, for poetic expedition, and from political expedition, from social expedition; and even from a historical expedition, because the nature of mythology is that it is steeped in a misunderstanding - and that misunderstanding never really becomes reconciled. It still exists, this mythology, post-misunderstanding, is really an attempt, a version, one vein in an attempt to explain or to reconcile this misunderstanding. But in it, it in itself is not a reconciliation. Reconciliation is still needed at the base, and that's why we have things like science, and different things which act upon it with all of its philosophies and its experiments and theories to try to achieve the reconciliation of the primary misunderstandings about things. Well, no matter what they are: naturals, the perceived supernaturals, the subnatural, et cetera et cetera...

But there's license. There's license to do as you will, to do as you see fit, to do that, to retain the authorial dimension of saying, "I am going to author mythology, the new mythology - and in this particular instance, the mythology of the diaspora - so, diasporian mythology." Within a modern context looking backwards towards history and not in the attempt, which I think is a new way of looking at it, not in an attempt to reconcile the totality of society to this point, but more to - or I guess that is the question. What is it? Because the attempt isn't to reconcile, I mean you're not trying to reconcile a misunderstanding of what you tryin' to do. Are you just trying to promote? Or are you just trying to point attention towards the misunderstanding? But even within this, there is a reality: It's not just mythology, it is an understanding, and that might be it. It's not that it's a misunderstanding which gives birth to myth. It is a understanding, it is already reconciled, it is already consolidated, it is already real. And but from that reality it births mythology, which kinda turns things on our heads a bit, I think. Alright. DROGAS.
summary:
The above text delves into the concept of mythology and its role in shaping our understanding of the world. The speaker reflects on their early exposure to Greek and Roman mythology and how it influenced their perception of storytelling and creation of myths. They discuss how mythology serves as a template for answering life's questions in a supernatural or fantastic manner, but also how modern myths, such as the cowboy or gangsta, play a role in shaping societal norms and values.

The speaker contemplates on the power of creating myths and the role of the author in shaping new mythologies, particularly within the context of diaspora. They suggest that mythology is not just about reconciling misunderstandings, but also about promoting certain ideas or drawing attention to societal issues. The text raises questions about the relationship between reality and mythology, and how one can influence the other.

Overall, the text delves into the complexities of mythology and its role in shaping our understanding of the world, while also questioning the nature of truth and storytelling. It explores themes of creation, misunderstanding, reconciliation, power, and the authorial role in shaping narratives.

The lyrics seem to touch on various themes such as consumerism, technology, identity, and the cyclical nature of life. The artist is portraying a satirical commentary on society's obsession with material possessions and the constant need for the latest and greatest products. The references to standing in line for new items, such as phones and sneakers, highlight how our culture places value on material goods.

The lyrics also delve into deeper existential questions, like the search for meaning and purpose in life. The references to the winter battle being won and the summer children being born could symbolize the struggles and joys we experience in life. The idea of the story going on and on suggests the cyclical nature of life and how we continue to navigate through different seasons and phases.

The mention of the thirteenth Zodiac sign and the burning witch could symbolize themes of change, transformation, and rebirth. The idea of going from dust to dust signifies the circle of life and how we ultimately return to the earth.

Overall, the lyrics offer a thought-provoking reflection on modern society, human existence, and the interconnectedness of life's different elements. The artist uses metaphorical language and vivid imagery to convey a deeper message about the complexities and contradictions of our world.

title: The Police: A Letter
lyrics:
A Letter

The police are not your friend. The police are not your enemy. The same could be said about the law. So let's say it. The law is not your friend and the law is not your enemy. So what are the police then if they are not friends nor enemies. Well let's get a definition of the word 'Police' from the dictionary: "the civil force of a national or local government, responsible for the prevention and detection of crime and the maintenance of public order." And while we're at it lets get a dictionary definition of 'Law' as well: "the system of rules that a particular country or community recognizes as regulating the actions of its members and may enforce by the imposition of penalties." Nowhere in the definition does it say "friend" or "enemy" even though some police officers can be friendly and some can be really antagonistic (see the famed "Good Cop/Bad Cop" routine for an explicit example) it is not the nature of their position in society to be friend or foe. So what are the police then? The firmest designation for the police is their primary title "Law Enforcement Officer" and again the law is neither your friend or foe so then the police are a merely reflection of the law. Police are the physical manifestation of the law. The police occupy a middle ground of sorts. They are mostly benign in the sense that if they have no particular law to enforce then they are powerless. Also where the law is broken and can't be seen or is out of the conscious knowledge of the police they are also powerless as is the law itself. Law is only powerful when it comes into direct contact with its child, Criminality. Crime and our relationship to crime is much closer to us than our relationship to the law. Everybody bends or breaks the law in some very minute capacity. We may speed on the highway from time to time. Throw litter on the ground. Lie on our taxes. Disregard a jury duty summons. Download pirated content. Where we feel the law doesn't "count" or "make sense" we are inclined to transgress the limits. Furthermore Crime is celebrated in all annals of entertainment and culture. In movies and books and song and TV. When was the last time you heard a song on the radio about the fabulous and sexy lifestyles of being a cop? In movies and TV it is much different as police officers are portrayed as being heroic figures but how many times within those same films or TV shows a police officer goes "outside" the law to rectify some injustice or solve some crime. How many movie cops had to "give up their badge" to the captain because they broke the rules to catch the bad guy? In effect they had to become criminals to enforce to the law. Think of Batman. Commissioner Gordon uses him when things get a little too out of hand in Gotham City and he needs somebody who isn't bound to the letter of the law and all that that entails to deal with the villainous hordes. This maybe "fictional" but then again is it really? How many real life cops put guns and drugs on people to get an arrest possibly on people who they know for a fact are committing serious crimes but can't prove it? How many cops "invent" a probable cause to effect a search of someone's property and eventually "find what they were looking for" even though what they found was not the initial reason they stopped the person? How many cops beat confessions out of people? How many cops flat out lie when it comes to what they saw or did during arrests and follow up investigations? How many cops have used terroristic threats to get people to comply to testifying or admitting to things they didn't commit? How many cops work for the same criminals they are employed to pursue in the forms of bribes and information? But then how many citizens do the same exact things? "Police Officer" and "Law Enforcement Officer" are just titles, roles, positions, names. No different than "typewriter" or "car." What gives these things life are the people that use them. Some people just do not know how to type or drive and it must be said that some people just don't know how to be police officers in strict accordance with the law. One problem is that becoming a police officer or law enforcement officer is a very structured and ordered bureaucratic process. It is very rigid and rather systematic. It is literally uniformed to stand as the visible and physical counterpoint to the non-uniformed wildness that is on the one smaller end, society itself and on the other larger end, criminality. Crime is subtle and blends well into the wild variety of society. Crime is successful because it is asymmetric and forever evolving. It can go unnoticed. Hence why the most successful police operations are done "undercover" and the most visible criminal activities are the least successful. The ability to blend into the "wildness" of society and mimic it is the best tactic for success outside of pure anarchy. Crime is highly adaptable. It is highly revered because its heroes have excellent leadership qualities and in some cases very deep philanthropic sentiments. Crime is the true equal opportunity employer and is one of the only organizations to successfully overcome the racial divides. Criminals are the embodiment of the material American Dream. Freedom (even from taxation!), upward mobility and the pursuit of happiness. All crimes have victims but one could say quite successfully that all things have victims. In the business world, victims are classified under the term externalities. For example, some people call perfectly legal mountain top removal coal mining a crime against humanity as it has the potential to build up then completely destroy entire communities not to mention the sometimes irreversible environmental externalities. Laws sometimes have a weird way of creating their own criminal enemies, hence the "child" term used earlier. Take for instance prohibition, it was a perfectly sound moral concept to combat what was seen by some as the scourge of drunkenness and all its hideous social and moral externalities, just imagine drunk driving back in the 20's! This perfectly sound moral law however single handedly created the mafia, the worlds greatest and most successful organized criminal enterprise. The emergence of the mafia lead to the creation of the FBI which was needed to be a "higher" form of law enforcement to combat the mob. The FBI tactics included all sorts of law bending and law creation to try and successfully tackle the problem the same government that employed them unwittingly created in the first place. The cultural impact of the mafia was instantaneous and deep even up to this day. For example, we all know off top who Al Capone was but would struggle to find out who the president of the United States was during the time Al Capone was alive. And without Google today I'd say some of us would probably never know or even care to find out. The legal limits were stretched to the fight the mafia then and they are still being stretched to this day to justify your parking ticket or your "failure to signal." So what does all this mean? Is it right? Is it wrong? Is it fair? Is there a solution? Unfortunately and fortunately there is no one solution. Law enforcement and criminality are like hand and glove. They are forever connected and as long as you have one you'll have the other and all the externalities from both sides that come along with them. Abuse of authority by authority will be balanced somewhere on the other side by abuse of the system by criminality. Freddy Grey dies unjustly in police custody on one side and El Chapo escapes from prison on the other side. An eye for and eye to be biblical about it. One hard solution to swallow for many is to just obey the law. Buuuuuut this "simple" solution also can create a set of dubious illegitimate children of its own because the law inextricably represents much more than its face value of "do not do and you will not be punished" for some "obey" is equated to "starve" or "go without" or "be poor" or "be insulted" or "be bored" or "be trapped in a vicious circle of economic and academically induced depression simply because I lost the biological lottery of life and was born into a family of second or third class citizens at a time and place where social status is dictated by race which also dictates access to the apparatuses of upward mobility etc etc etc..." Sometimes "obey" explicitly means die. This is the root of the plague of vendetta that is sweeping through Chicago. The ever viral and ever rational and true "Kill Or Be Killed" mentality. For some "obey" MEANS "punishment." This misunderstanding of metaphorical process when it comes to how we refer, frame and live through the narratives of our individual lives is what causes much of the conflict. Objective law has little wiggle room for subjective reality. What "law enforcement officer" means in a dictionary and the courts can be far from the definition that it has on the streets and in practice. Police officers can be defined on the streets as surely protecting and serving but protecting and serving the wills of a corrupt authoritative system that if allowed to have its way will mean poverty forever and access denied ad infinitum. Police officers must be trained to assess not only the dangers of a situation but also the desperation of a situation. Is it just a coincidence that a synonym for criminal is "Desperado"? Law Enforcement has to become much more in tune and educated with the needs (material, PSYCHOLOGICAL, spiritual and cognitive) of the communities it is tasked with patrolling and if they are unable or unwilling to take on the entire scope of their position then they should find work elsewhere. Most police will respond to this by saying that such a comprehensive approach is not in there job description and will have little to no effect on the streets. One must then in reply confront them with the nature of law itself. Law is connected to the mentalities of man. It seeks to control or less invasively patrol the passions and actions of man which stem directly from his mind. And if you cannot fully comprehend the mind of a man as an externality of the environment in which he inhabits then how can you fully understand the mechanics of law itself? Again Law and the mind are like hand and glove. Some cops will say that it is for the courts to decide. However, one must argue back plainly that judges, prison guards and prosecutors don't walk the streets or patrol the beats and they rely on and TRUST police officers and their presupposed understanding of the law to bring cases before them that only meet or exceed the requirements set out by the law. That is why POLICE OFFICERS HAVE TO TESTIFY IN COURT because they are considered to be expert witnesses in terms of criminal justice and are expected to expose the very fine details of active criminality that a DA stuck in an office or a judge stuck behind a bench does not have the time nor mental hard drive space to process thoroughly. Be clear on two things: This is not meant to be a belittling or a rebuke of the police or the letter and spirit of the law. I have 3 siblings with long careers in law enforcement as police officers, correctional officers and sheriffs. This is also not an approval of criminality. I have exponentially many more family and friend who have been involved in the world of crime and it is nothing to brag about or applaud as a successful life to lead. Most of the time it has ended in death or prison or both. Both these institutions are reflections of the human condition and our understandings and misunderstandings of the way the world is "supposed" to work. The death of Sandra Bland is the perfect example of when these two amorphous and wandering institutions get it all the way wrong. Sandra perceived the law enforcement officer to be a law enforcement officer and all that that entails in control of his emotions and strictly subservient to the rule of law when in fact he retreated to criminality and reverted to lawlessness to prosecute what he perceived to be a disrespectful criminal threat in Sandra as opposed to her being a law abiding but pressurized citizen questioning the lawfulness of her stop. Her death in jail is a reflection of the misunderstanding of the mental pressure even the tiniest amount of perceived injustice can do to a person. While I hesitate to judge her cause of death I feel comfortable in saying that if it was suicide it speaks to the depth of the belief we as humans have in right and wrong. Sometimes people would rather die than face the injustices of this world and it doesn't need to be years or decades to decay someone to such a state it can take hours or days. Even seconds. The direct connection between The Law and The Mind is something that needs to taken very seriously by not only police officers but also by the rank and file citizen. The FULL scope of Law and Law Enforcement and Criminality and what effects they all have on the already overly sensitized and tandemically overly desensitized psyches of the communities they inhabit needs to become a dominant issue in culture. So while law enforcement officers may by definition not be our "friends" it might be time that they damn well think about becoming them or at least stray from acting as our enemies. And it might do us well to accept them as "friends" if they honestly extend the offer and not make ourselves enemies to them based on what we see in the trending multimediums as "Brand Cop." Otherwise we together run the risk of giving birth to a new child, one that will feed not on milk but instead off the flesh and blood of its parents.

Sincerely,

Wasalu "Lupe" Jaco
summary:
The letter addresses the complex relationship between law enforcement, criminality, and society. It highlights how the police are not inherently friends or enemies, but rather a reflection of the law they are tasked with enforcing. The letter delves into the blurred lines between obeying the law and feeling oppressed by it, as well as the impact of external factors such as poverty and systemic injustices on individuals' perceptions of authority.

One of the major themes in the letter is the idea of the law as a powerful force that can both protect and harm individuals, depending on their circumstances. It also explores the role of police officers as both enforcers of the law and potential abusers of authority, questioning the balance between upholding justice and perpetuating injustice.

The letter also touches on the societal implications of criminality and law enforcement, highlighting the ways in which these institutions can shape individuals' perceptions of right and wrong, and the devastating consequences that can result from misinterpretations or misuses of power.

Overall, the letter challenges readers to consider the complexities of law enforcement and criminality, urging both civilians and police officers to strive for a more empathetic and understanding approach to justice and social order.

summary:
The lyrics from Lupe Fiasco's song touch on themes of social justice, police brutality, racism, and the fight for equality. The verses address the violence inflicted by police officers, particularly towards marginalized communities, and the need for accountability and justice. The lyrics also delve into the historical context of oppression and discrimination faced by Black people, referencing figures like Rodney King and alluding to the Civil Rights movement.

Metaphors such as "beat him in the head" and "kick him in the neck" are used to symbolize the physical violence and aggression perpetuated by those in power. The lyrics also reference societal issues like climate change and wealth inequality, drawing attention to the interconnected nature of social and environmental injustices.

Overall, the song serves as a powerful commentary on the state of society, calling for awareness, action, and solidarity in the face of systemic oppression and injustice. It encourages listeners to question the status quo, challenge authority, and strive towards creating a more just and equitable world.

The lyrics also contain metaphors that convey a sense of power and dominance, such as comparing his flow to bullets and his words to a weapon. He addresses the struggles he has faced and the obstacles he has overcome, emphasizing the importance of self-belief and determination in achieving success. The lyrics also touch on themes of spirituality, expressing gratitude for blessings and seeking forgiveness for shortcomings.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of empowerment, self-assurance, and a determination to continue pursuing greatness in the face of challenges and adversity.

He talks about detaching from negative influences and finding peace within oneself. The idea of going to a "pure land" and having a festival for the rest of you could symbolize finding inner peace and healing.

Overall, the lyrics convey themes of emotional turmoil, self-discovery, and the journey towards healing and letting go. The metaphor of driving with the windows down and dancing with friends may represent the process of moving on and finding joy in new experiences despite feelings of loneliness and longing.

The lyrics of this song "Superstar" by Lupe Fiasco featuring Matthew Santos touch on themes of fame, celebrity, the pressures of the entertainment industry, and the desire for recognition and validation. The song portrays the struggles and challenges that come with being in the spotlight, such as dealing with the scrutiny of the media, the expectations of fans, and the constant need to prove oneself as a "superstar."

Throughout the song, there are references to the cameras, microphones, and audience members seeking a show, highlighting the constant performance and spectacle that comes with fame. The lyrics also touch on the idea of being true to oneself in the face of fame and not letting it change who you are as a person.

The metaphor of being a "superstar" is used to represent the desire for success and recognition, but also the pitfalls and challenges that come with it. The lyrics convey a sense of longing for authenticity and a desire to break free from the constraints and expectations of fame.

Overall, the song explores the complex and often contradictory nature of celebrity culture, highlighting the highs and lows of being a "superstar" in the entertainment industry.

title: Life, Death & Love From San Fransisco
lyrics:

She was done at the moment that the tea fell

Doesn't satisfy like a game of pool might
Thinking "what if Fantasia had a broom strike? "
Tune right out of that school life

So what do you do like?

And then left him
Like the Roots left Geffen
And the state Howlin' Wolf left Chess in
Stop to watch flows have an unpaid session on the steps of a Westin
She really need to check in
And to apologize to her best friend
New bras to put her chest in

summary:
The lyrics paint a vivid picture of a woman navigating through the complexities of love and life. The speaker expresses the challenges and hardships of love, comparing it to various activities like golfing, gardening, and parole board pardoning. The woman in the song is depicted as someone who has faced difficult experiences, such as dealing with difficult men and finding herself in precarious situations. The lyrics also touch on themes of resilience, self-discovery, and the search for authenticity.

The use of metaphors, such as picking flowers like guitar strings, symbolizes the woman's search for beauty and meaning in her life. The mention of the American flag and splitting a dollar bill in half may allude to themes of division, identity, and the struggle to find one's place in society. The references to music, art, and culture throughout the lyrics add depth to the woman's character and suggest a longing for connection and understanding.

Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of disillusionment and vulnerability, but also resilience and determination. The woman in the song seems to be searching for authenticity and meaning in a world that is often harsh and unforgiving. The lyrics capture the complexity of human emotions and experiences, making the listener reflect on their own journey through love and life.

The lyrics in the above passage are rich with themes of creativity, self-expression, and imagination. Virgil Abloh, a renowned artist and designer, is discussed in the opening lines, emphasizing the importance of returning to a childlike sense of wonder and creativity. The verse by Lupe Fiasco delves into the idea of creating one's own identity and expressing oneself through fashion and style.

The metaphor of a tailor making his own suit from scratch is used to symbolize the idea of crafting one's own narrative and identity. The thread representing breath and fabric symbolizing youth suggest that the essence of a person is deeply intertwined with their experiences and the way they choose to present themselves to the world.

The lyrics also touch on themes of authenticity and individuality, as seen in lines like "When you eat soul food in the tux I mean what the fuck?" This can be interpreted as a message about staying true to oneself and embracing one's heritage and culture.

Overall, the lyrics highlight the power of self-expression and creativity as a means of reclaiming one's agency and identity in a world that often seeks to box individuals into a predetermined narrative. It encourages listeners to embrace their imagination and utilize their creativity to shape their own stories and break free from societal constraints.

summary:
The above lyrics seem to convey the idea of facing one's fears and challenges head-on. The door represents the threshold between safety and the unknown, symbolizing the struggle between wanting to stay protected and the need to confront difficulties. The armor and sword could represent the tools we use to protect ourselves and fight back against adversity.

The lyrics also touch on themes of responsibility and duty, as the speaker acknowledges the weight of the hopes and expectations placed upon them. There is a sense of resilience and determination in the face of overwhelming odds, as the speaker prepares to boldly face whatever lies on the other side of the door.

Overall, the lyrics convey a message of courage, perseverance, and the willingness to confront challenges, no matter how scary or daunting they may seem. The door serves as a powerful metaphor for the obstacles we face in life, and the importance of facing them with strength and determination.

The lyrics seem to be discussing themes of materialism, superficiality, and manipulation in relationships. The speaker boasts about his wealth and status, using it to impress and manipulate women. He talks about flashing his watch, showing off his chain, and driving a Range Rover to attract women, while also acknowledging that he is playing games and not being genuine in his interactions. 

The metaphor of using material possessions and luxury items to attract and manipulate others is prevalent throughout the song. The speaker talks about spending money on designer clothes, cars, and expensive items to impress women, even though deep down he doesn't see the value in it. The lyrics also touch on the idea of using deception and manipulation to get what you want in relationships, rather than being authentic and genuine.

Overall, the lyrics suggest a shallow and self-serving approach to relationships, where appearances and material possessions hold more value than true connection and sincerity. The speaker seems to be aware of his own insincerity and the emptiness of his actions, but continues to play the game in order to get what he wants.

title: EOW US Finals 2019 freestyle
lyrics: Time out, time out, time out! Before we leave can we get Lupe to rap???
summary:
The lyrics "Time out, time out, time out! Before we leave can we get Lupe to rap???" suggest a sense of urgency and excitement. The repetition of "time out" could imply a need to pause or stop before moving on, possibly to pay attention to something important. The request to hear Lupe rap adds to the anticipation and desire for something entertaining or engaging.

In terms of themes and metaphors, the lyrics could represent a desire for a change of pace or a break from the routine. The idea of "time out" could also symbolize a moment of reflection or introspection before moving forward. The request to hear Lupe rap could symbolize a call for creativity, expression, or authenticity in the midst of a hectic or mundane situation. Overall, the lyrics convey a sense of enthusiasm and a desire for something memorable or impactful to happen before moving on to the next thing.

But I'm a keep up with mine, keep on striving and surviving no

[Repeat Chorus]
See everybodys got their own problems that their going through
I take it day by day, it's only thing that I can do
So I live for me as you live for you
But you can't be me unless you walk in my shoes

[Chorus x2]
Walk walk, walk walk, walk walk - walk in my shoes [x 2]
summary:
The lyrics convey a sense of individuality, self-reliance, and perseverance in the face of challenges. The speaker expresses a determination to live their life on their own terms, not letting others dictate their path or steal their light. The repetition of the phrase "walk in my shoes" suggests a call for empathy and understanding, as well as a recognition of the unique struggles and experiences that shape each person.

The theme of resilience is also present, with the speaker acknowledging the difficulties they face but refusing to give up. The metaphor of walking in someone else's shoes signifies the idea of understanding another person's perspective and struggles before passing judgement. It suggests a willingness to empathize and see the world from a different point of view.

Overall, the lyrics convey a message of self-empowerment, authenticity, and the importance of staying true to oneself despite outside pressures. It encourages listeners to embrace their own journey, face challenges head-on, and continue striving for their goals despite obstacles.

title: Glass of Water
lyrics:
[Verse 1]
A glass of water
Held up to the lips of the marauder
Dry and flakey looking like they haven't had a sip in days
The glass kisses the lips, drawing from them instant praise
They also says, I was more rudderless than a ship
Without a captain adrift
On the ocean of life, no destination in sight
But now I see, what it means to be in need of the preservation of life

[Verse 2]
A glass of water with a goldfish inside
Used to swimming in the river, this a whole different vibe
Feel like a fish outta water, now harbors in new tank
Dressed in camouflage, soldiers in uniforms salute it from the ranks
Like thanks for your service, and everything you do behind the scenes
And beneath the surface, like a disguise
In the distorted reflection of the surface of the fish eyes

[Interlude: Instrumental]
Yeah, yeah, uh, uh
Yeah, yeah

[Verse 3]
Glasses of water, eyes filled with tears
Got the world looking blurry
Like a Monet painting
Not a cloud in the sky
But each cloud of eye of my hard times
And crying will have the whole world raining
Umbrellas provide shelter
Put the tent up
Release the pent-up emotions to feel better
Growing pains, sewing lanes, irrigation is making the fields wetter
That's a glass of water, the scent reminds you of the tap from your childhood home
Like an old friend, you relish the familiar taste
No matter how mundane that it may have been and
The right glass might send you to a past life
Make you want to live your new day like a last night
As you maraud through the weather that you can't see
Stick an umbrella in it if you feelin' fancy, yeah
summary:
The lyrics explore the importance of water as a symbol of life, preservation, and transformation. The first verse depicts someone who has been lacking nourishment, both physically and spiritually, and finds rejuvenation and direction through a simple glass of water. This could be a metaphor for finding hope and purpose in times of struggle.

The second verse introduces the image of a goldfish in a new environment, symbolizing adaptability and resilience. It highlights the idea of embracing change and finding strength in unfamiliar surroundings.

The third verse delves into the emotional aspect of water, comparing tears to rain that nourishes the soul and allows for growth. The reference to childhood memories and familiar tastes in water emphasizes the connection between past experiences and present emotions.

Overall, the lyrics seem to suggest that water is not only a physical necessity for life but also a source of emotional comfort, nostalgia, and transformation. The various metaphors and themes in the song serve to illustrate the multifaceted nature of water and its significance in human experience.

The lyrics seem to convey a sense of being trapped by societal norms and expectations, represented by the metaphor of "the box". The protagonist of the song is stuck in a cycle of watching and imitating others, unable to break free and find their own voice. The "box" symbolizes conformity, control, and suppression of individuality.

The repetition of "And he never lies" could suggest that the protagonist is living a facade, never being true to themselves or expressing their own thoughts and feelings. They are constantly absorbing external influences without truly understanding or questioning them.

The bridge highlights the theme of identity and self-awareness, questioning who the protagonist truly is behind the mask they put on to fit in with society. The mention of hiding scars and stars could represent hiding one's pain and inner light, conforming to societal standards instead of embracing one's true self.

Overall, the lyrics explore themes of conformity, self-discovery, and the struggle to break free from societal expectations and find one's own voice. The metaphor of the box is used effectively to illustrate the feeling of being trapped and controlled by external influences.

These lyrics convey the pain and struggle of a relationship that has left emotional scars. The metaphor of "battle scars" represents the lingering effects of past hurt and trauma inflicted in the relationship. The narrator is conflicted between wanting to move on and feeling the need to hold on to what once was. The references to war and fighting highlight the intense emotional turmoil and internal conflict the narrator is experiencing.

The lyrics also touch on the idea of trying to heal from past wounds but never truly being able to let go. The repeated refrain of "These battle scars don't look like they're fading" emphasizes the lasting impact of the pain and heartbreak. The lyrics suggest that the narrator is stuck in a cycle of trying to heal and move on, but continuously getting pulled back into the pain and memories of the past.

Overall, the song delves into themes of love, heartbreak, and resilience in the face of emotional trauma. The use of powerful metaphors and imagery paints a vivid picture of the struggles and complexities of navigating the aftermath of a tumultuous relationship.

Overall, the song "Touch the Sky" is a powerful anthem about reaching for your dreams, overcoming challenges, and ultimately rising to the top. It serves as a reminder to keep pushing forward and never give up on your aspirations.

The lyrics suggest that even though wounds may heal, the scars remain as a constant reminder of the hurt and pain experienced.

The song delves into the internal conflict of trying to hold on to a relationship even when all signs point to letting go. The references to feeling like a soldier on the frontline, trying to fight for love but ultimately feeling defeated and wounded, capture the intense emotions of trying to make a relationship work despite all odds.

summary:
These lyrics explore the concept of rich individuals making poor decisions, both in their personal lives and in the broader societal context. The artists, Rick Ross, Lupe Fiasco, and Wale, all share their perspectives on the consequences of materialism, lack of guidance, and the struggle for identity in a world dominated by wealth and power.

Rick Ross highlights the cycle of poverty and criminality that can trap individuals, leading them to make detrimental choices for temporary gains. Lupe Fiasco delves into the societal pressure to conform to materialism and the negative impact it can have on one's sense of self-worth and values. Wale adds to this by discussing the superficiality of consumerism and the emptiness that can result from chasing material possessions.

The repeated refrain of "rich niggas making poor decisions" emphasizes the irony of individuals who have access to resources but still fall into destructive patterns. The artists also touch on themes of family dynamics, lack of mentorship, and the allure of quick wealth.

In the outro, Lupe Fiasco introduces the idea of "poor niggas making rich decisions," suggesting that true wealth may come from making wise choices, regardless of one's financial status. This concept challenges the conventional idea of success and highlights the importance of inner values and moral integrity.

Overall, these lyrics serve as a commentary on the complexities of wealth, poverty, and decision-making, urging listeners to consider the true meaning of success and fulfillment in a materialistic world.

The lyrics describe a scene in a club where women are waiting in line for the bathroom, showcasing their glamorous and hedonistic lifestyle. 

There are references to drug use, luxury brands, and high society living throughout the song. The chorus repeats the image of girls standing in line for the bathroom, which can symbolize the superficiality and vanity of the party scene. 

Each verse adds its own perspective on this lifestyle, with mentions of wealth, fame, and the allure of living in the fast lane. The metaphor of being "on fire" can represent the excitement and intensity of this lifestyle, but also the destructiveness of it.

Overall, the lyrics paint a picture of a lavish and excessive world where status and image are everything, but also hint at the emptiness and consequences that come with it.
